summary: Astronauts are exposed to harsh conditions, including cosmic radiation and microgravity . Spaceflight elongates human telomeres in peripheral blood .
MuSCs become activated, proliferate, and differentiate in a series of coordinated steps, to repair muscle damage . In the context of muscle atrophy, MuSC properties are less clear .
A combination of IR and HLS resulted in telomere elongation, specifically in myogenic cell populations, which did not recover upon a short duration reloading of hindlimbs .

IR exposure alone had no effects on kidney or spleen weights, but it did cause significant reductions in testes weights, when compared to sham/control mice . HLS also had deleterious effects on testes gross size and normalized weight .

HLS + IR MuSC telomeres were assessed, but we found significant telomere lengthening, as compared to all other groups . Gastrocnemius cryosections were stained with the MuSC marker, Pax7 . We evaluated MuSC populations and properties .

Myonuclei, which were defined as localizing within muscle fibers and staining negative for the stem cell marker VCAM, were examined for telomere length changes . Similar to what was found for MuSCs, myonucles also displayed increased telomeres in HLS + IR gastrocnemius muscles .

The gastrocnemius muscles of recovered mice were larger than HLS + IR mice and were of similar size to controls . The recovery did not interfere with general organ mass . The recovered mice retained elongated telomere length and continued to increase further .
We found low telomerase activity in experimental gastrocnemius muscles . We found no significant changes between control muscles and HLS + IR .

Astronauts experience adverse health effects on long-duration missions, including headaches, dizziness, congestion, changes in blood cells, and fatigue, as well as severe bone and muscle loss . A better understanding of the causes of such impediments to explorer health in an earthbound model could serve beneficial effects in the development of additional countermeasures .

A growing body of evidence suggests that very long telomeres may be problematic in human cells, as these telomeric fragility could develop instabilities . Tight control of telomere length homeostasis is essential .
Recent evidence has shown telomere lengthening in the blood cells of Mount Everest climbers during different points of peak ascent .

A major difference between mice and humans is telomere length, with many mouse strains having ∼8-fold longer telomeres than humans . Skeletal muscle cell telomerel length was not examined in astronaut studies . Future investigations using animal models in spaceflight would presumably mimic the muscle defects seen in astronauts .

Mice were anesthetized with an isoflurane vaporizer (2.5% v/v is ofluranes to oxygen) and wrapped with surgical tape . Mice hung for a period of 3 weeks, with or without a 2-week recovery period where mice were placed in conventional housing . After 2 Gy exposure, mice were returned to conventional

Images were processed using the extended depth of focus algorithm in the accompanying Nikon elements microscope software . Images were exported as 16-bit monochrome tiffs and analyzed using the free analysis software, Telometer 3.0.6 .
The article is published in the Nature Research journal journal Nature Research . The article includes a report of the study . The report was published on October 31, 2013 .
